title: Banja Luka
text:
Banja Luka (, ) or Banjaluka (, ) is the <a href="List%20of%20cities%20in%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">second largest city</a> in <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> and the largest city of <a href="Republika%20Srpska">Republika Srpska</a>. Banja Luka is also the de facto capital of this <a href="Political%20divisions%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">entity</a>. It is the traditional centre of the densely-forested <a href="Bosanska%20Krajina">Bosanska Krajina</a> region of northwestern <a href="Bosnia%20%28region%29">Bosnia</a>. , the city proper has a population of 138,963, while its administrative area comprises a total of 185,042 inhabitants.
The city is home to the <a href="University%20of%20Banja%20Luka">University of Banja Luka</a> as well as numerous entity and state institutions for Republika Srpska and Bosnia and Herzegovina respectively. The city lies on the <a href="Vrbas%20%28river%29">Vrbas River</a> and is well known in the countries of the <a href="Socialist%20Federal%20Republic%20of%20Yugoslavia">former Yugoslavia</a> for being full of tree-lined avenues, boulevards, gardens, and parks. Banja Luka was designated European city of sport in 2018.
Name.
The name "Banja Luka" was first mentioned in a document dated to 6 February 1494 by <a href="Vladislaus%20II%20of%20Hungary">Ladislaus II of Hungary</a>. The name is interpreted as the 'Ban's meadow', from the words "<a href="ban%20%28title%29">ban</a>" (a mediaeval noble title), and "luka" ('valley' or 'meadow'). The identity of the ban and the meadow in question remains uncertain, and <a href="popular%20etymology">popular etymology</a> combines the modern words "banja" ('bath' or 'spa'), or "bajna" ('marvelous') and "luka" ('port'). A different interpretation is suggested by the Hungarian name "Lukácsbánya", in English 'Luke's Mine'. In modern usage, the name is pronounced and usually written as one word ("Banjaluka").
Geography.
Overview.
Banja Luka covers some of land in <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> and is situated on both banks of the <a href="Vrbas%20%28river%29">Vrbas</a> in the Banja Luka valley, which is characteristically flat within the otherwise hilly region. Banja Luka's centre lies <a href="Above%20mean%20sea%20level">above sea level</a>.
The source of the Vrbas River is about to the south at the <a href="Vranica">Vranica</a> mountain. Its tributaries—the Suturlija, the Crkvena, and the <a href="Vrbanja%20%28river%29">Vrbanja</a>—flow into the Vrbas at various points in the city. A number of springs can be found nearby.
The area around Banja Luka is mostly woodland and acre fields, although there are many mountains further from the city, especially south from the city. The most notable of these mountains are Ponir (743 m), Osmača (950 m), Manjača (1,214 m), Čemernica (1,338 m), and Tisovac (1,173 m). These are all part of the <a href="Dinaric%20Alps">Dinaric Alps</a> mountain range.

Climate.
Banja Luka has a moderate <a href="humid%20subtropical%20climate">humid subtropical climate</a> with mild winters, infrequent frosts, and warm summers. The warmest month of the year is July, with an average temperature of . The coldest month of the year is January, when temperatures average around .
The annual precipitation for the city is about . Banja Luka has an average of 104 rainy days a year. Due to the city's relatively high latitude and inland location, it snows in Banja Luka almost every year during the winter period. Strong winds can come from the north and northeast. Sometimes, southern winds bring hot air from the Adriatic sea.
History.
Roman times.
The history of inhabitation of the area of Banja Luka dates back to ancient times. There is substantial evidence of <a href="Roman%20Empire">Roman</a> presence in the region during the first few centuries A.D., including the fort "Kastel" () in the centre of the city. The area comprising Banja Luka was entirely in the kingdom of Illyria and then a part of the Roman province of <a href="Illyricum%20%28Roman%20province%29">Illyricum</a>, which split into provinces of <a href="Pannonia">Pannonia</a> and <a href="Dalmatia">Dalmatia</a> of which Castra became a part. Ancient Illyrian maps call the settlement in Banja Luka's present day location as Ad Ladios, a settlement located on the river <a href="Vrbas%20%28river%29">Vrbas</a>.
Middle Ages.
Slavs settled in the Balkans in the 6th century. Mediaeval fortresses in the vicinity of Banja Luka include <a href="Vrbas%20fortress">Vrbas</a> (1224), Župa Zemljanik (1287), <a href="Kotor%20Varo%C5%A1">Kotor Varoš</a> (1323), Zvečaj (1404), and Bočac (1446). In one document written by king
<a href="Vladislaus%20II%20of%20Hungary">Vladislav II</a> on 6 February 1494 Juraj Mikulasić was mentioned as <a href="castellan">castellan</a> of Banja Luka. Below the town was a smaller settlement with one Catholic monastery.
Ottoman rule.
Banja Luka fell to the Ottomans in 1527. It became the seat of the <a href="Sanjak%20of%20Bosnia">Sanjak of Bosnia</a> some time prior to 1554, until 1580 when the <a href="Bosnia%20Eyalet">Bosnia Eyalet</a> was established. Bosnian beylerbeys were seated in Banja Luka until 1639. <a href="Ferhad%20Pasha%20Sokolovi%C4%87">Ferhad Pasha Sokolović</a>, a relative of Grand Vizier <a href="Sokollu%20Mehmed%20Pasha">Mehmed-pasha Sokolović</a>, had upon his return to Bosnia in 1574, begun the building of over 200 buildings ranging from artisan and sales shops to wheat warehouses, baths and mosques. Among more important commissions were the <a href="Ferhat%20Pasha%20Mosque">Ferhadija</a> and <a href="Arnaudija%20Mosque">Arnaudija</a> mosques during whose construction plumbing infrastructure was laid out, that served surrounding residential areas. This stimulated the economic and urban development of Banja Luka, which soon became one of the leading commercial and political centres in Bosnia. It was also the central sanjak in the Bosnia Eyalet. In 1688, the city was burned down by the Austrian army, but it quickly recovered. Later periodic intrusions by the Austrian army stimulated military developments in Banja Luka, which made it into a strategic military centre. Orthodox churches and monasteries near Banja Luka were built in the 19th century. Also, <a href="Sephardic%20Jew">Sephardic Jew</a>s and <a href="Trappists">Trappists</a> migrated to the city in the 19th century and contributed to the early industrialisation of the region by building mills, breweries, brick factories, textile factories and other important structures.
The <a href="Mariastern%20Abbey%2C%20Banja%20Luka">Trappist monastery</a> built in the 19th century lent its name to the neighbourhood of "Trapisti" and has left a large legacy in the area through its <a href="Trappista%20cheese">Trappist cheese</a> and its beer production.
In 1835 and 1836, during Ottoman administration, numerous people from Banja Luka emigrated to <a href="Le%C5%A1nica%2C%20Serbia">Lešnica</a>, <a href="Lipnica%20%28Loznica%29">Lipnica</a> and <a href="Loznica">Loznica</a>, the villages around Loznica, and to <a href="%C5%A0abac">Šabac</a>.
Austro-Hungarian rule.
Despite its leading position in the region, Banja Luka as a city was not modernised until <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20campaign%20in%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina%20in%201878">Austro-Hungarian occupation</a> in the late 19th century. Railroads, schools, factories, and infrastructure appeared, and were developed, which turned Banja Luka into a modern city.
Yugoslavia.
After World War I, the town became the capital of the <a href="Vrbas%20Banovina">Vrbas Banovina</a>, a province of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Yugoslavia">Kingdom of Yugoslavia</a>.
The provincial capital owed its rapid progress to the first Ban Svetislav Milosavljević. During that time, the Banski dvor and its twin sister, the Administration building, the Serbian Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity, a theatre and a museum were built, the Grammar School was renovated, the Teachers College enlarged, a city bridge was built and the park renovated.
125 elementary schools were functioning in Banja Luka in 1930. The revolutionary ideas of the time were incubated by the "Pelagić" association and the Students' Club. Banja Luka naturally became the organisational centre of anti-fascist work in the region.
World War II.
During World War II, Banja Luka was occupied by <a href="Axis%20powers">Axis</a> troops and was included into the <a href="Ante%20Paveli%C4%87">Pavelić's</a> <a href="Independent%20State%20of%20Croatia">Independent State of Croatia</a> (NDH). The fascist <a href="Ustashe">Ustashe</a> regime committed the <a href="Genocide%20of%20Serbs%20in%20the%20Independent%20State%20of%20Croatia">Genocide of the Serbs</a> and <a href="The%20Holocaust%20in%20the%20Independent%20State%20of%20Croatia">the Holocaust</a>. Most of Banja Luka's Serbs and Jews were deported to concentration camps such as <a href="Jasenovac%20concentration%20camp">Jasenovac</a> and <a href="Stara%20Gradi%C5%A1ka%20concentration%20camp">Stara Gradiška</a>. The Jasenovac camp was one of the largest <a href="extermination%20camp">extermination camp</a>s in Europe, which was notorious for its high mortality rate and the barbaric practices which occurred in it. On 7 February 1942, Ustashe paramilitaries, led by a Franciscan friar, <a href="Miroslav%20Filipovi%C4%87">Miroslav Filipović</a> (aka Tomislav Filipović-Majstorović), killed more than 2,300 Serbs (among them 500 children) in <a href="Drakuli%C4%87%2C%20Banja%20Luka">Drakulić</a>, <a href="Motike%2C%20Banja%20Luka">Motike</a> and <a href="%C5%A0argovac">Šargovac</a> (a part of the Banja Luka municipality).
The city's <a href="Cathedral%20of%20Christ%20the%20Saviour%2C%20Banja%20Luka">Cathedral of Christ the Saviour</a> and Orthodox church of the Holy Trinity were totally demolished by the Ustashe, as was the Church of St. George in <a href="Petri%C4%87evac">Petrićevac</a>. The <a href="Eparchy%20of%20Banja%20Luka">Bishop of Banja Luka</a>, <a href="Platon%20of%20Banja%20Luka">Platon Jovanović</a>, was arrested by the Ustaše on 5 May 1941, and was tortured and killed. His body was thrown into the <a href="Vrbanja%20%28river%29">Vrbanja river</a>. The city was liberated by the <a href="Yugoslav%20Partisans">Yugoslav Partisans</a> on 22 April 1945.
1969 earthquake.
On 26 and 27 October 1969, two devastating earthquakes (6.0 and 6.4 on the <a href="Richter%20magnitude%20scale">Richter scale</a>) damaged many buildings in Banja Luka. Around 20 to 23 people were killed, and over a thousand injured. A large building called Titanik in the centre of the town was razed to the ground, and the area was later turned into a central public square. With contributions from all over Yugoslavia, Banja Luka was repaired and rebuilt. During this period a large Serb population moved to the city from the surrounding villages, and from more distant areas in Herzegovina.
Bosnian War.
During the 1990s, the city underwent considerable changes when the <a href="Bosnian%20War">Bosnian War</a> broke out. Upon the declaration of <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnian-Herzegovinian</a> independence and the establishment of the <a href="Republika%20Srpska">Republika Srpska</a>, Banja Luka became the <a href="de%20facto">de facto</a> centre of the entity's politics.
Nearly all of Banja Luka's Croats and Bosniaks were expelled during the war and all of the city's 16 mosques, including the <a href="Ferhat%20Pasha%20Mosque">Ferhat Pasha Mosque</a>, were stacked with explosives and destroyed. A court ruling resulted in the authorities of Banja Luka having to pay $42 million for the destruction of the mosques. Later, an estimated 40,000 Serbs from Croat- and Bosniak-dominated areas of Bosnia, having been exiled from their homes, settled in Banja Luka. However, the Banja Luka district court later overturned the ruling stating that the claims had exceeded a three-year statute of limitations. The Bosniak community vowed to appeal against the decision.
On 7 May 2001, several thousand Serb nationalists attacked a group of Bosniaks and members of the diplomatic corps attending a ceremony of marking the reconstruction of the historic 16th-century <a href="Ferhat%20Pasha%20Mosque">Ferhadija mosque</a>. There were indications of police collaboration. More than 30 individuals were injured during the attack, and on 26 May, Murat Badić, who had been in a coma after the attack, died from head injuries. Fourteen Bosnian Serb nationalists were jailed for starting the riots.
Demographics.
The 2013 census in Bosnia indicated a population of 185,042, overwhelmingly Serbs.
Government.
Banja Luka plays an important role on different levels of Bosnia and Herzegovina's government structures. Banja Luka is the centre of the government for the Municipality of Banja Luka. A number of entity and state institutions are seated in the city. The Republika Srpska Government and the <a href="National%20Assembly%20%28Republika%20Srpska%29">National Assembly</a> are based in Banja Luka.
The Bosnia and Herzegovina State Agencies based in the city include the Indirect Taxation (VAT) Authority, the Deposit Insurance Agency as well as a branch of the <a href="Central%20Bank%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Central Bank of Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> (formerly the National Bank of Republika Srpska). Austria, Croatia, France, Germany, <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a>, the United Kingdom and the United States maintain diplomatic representation through <a href="Consul%20%28representative%29">consulates-general</a> in Banja Luka.
As of 2021, the mayor is <a href="Dra%C5%A1ko%20Stanivukovi%C4%87">Draško Stanivuković</a> of the <a href="Party%20of%20Democratic%20Progress">Party of Democratic Progress</a>, elected in <a href="2020%20Bosnian%20municipal%20elections">2020</a>.
Economy.
In 1981 Banja Luka's GDP per capita was 97% of the Yugoslav average.
Although the city itself was not directly affected by the Bosnian war in the early 1990s, its economy was. In this period Banja Luka fell behind the world in key areas such as technology, resulting in a rather stagnant economy. However, in recent years, the financial services sector has gained in importance in the city. In 2002, the trading began on the newly established <a href="Banja%20Luka%20Stock%20Exchange">Banja Luka Stock Exchange</a>. The number of companies listed, the trading volume and the number of investors have increased significantly. A number of big companies such as <a href="Telekom%20Srpske">Telekom Srpske</a>, Rafinerija ulja Modriča, <a href="Banjalu%C4%8Dka%20Pivara">Banjalučka Pivara</a> and Vitaminka are all listed on the exchange and are traded regularly. Investors, apart from those from <a href="Slovenia">Slovenia</a>, Croatia and <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a>, now include a number of investment funds from the EU, and from <a href="Norway">Norway</a>, the United States, Japan and China.
A number of financial services regulators, such as the <a href="Republika%20Srpska%20Securities%20Commission">Republika Srpska Securities Commission</a> and the RS Banking Agency are headquartered in Banja Luka. This, along with the fact that some of the major banks in Bosnia, the Deposit Insurance Agency and the <a href="value-added%20tax">value-added tax</a> (VAT) authority are all based in the city, has helped Banja Luka establish itself as a major financial centre of the country.

Culture.
The Museum of <a href="Republika%20Srpska">Republika Srpska</a> inherited the Ethnographic Museum established in 1930, and broadened its setting with collections of archeology, history, art history and nature. The <a href="Museum%20of%20Modern%20Art%20of%20Republika%20Srpska">Museum of Modern Art of Republika Srpska</a>, also called MSURS, the Museum of Contemporary Art, displays exhibitions of both domestic and worldwide artists.
Banja Luka is home to the National Theatre and National Library, both dating from the first half of the 20th century, and of numerous other theatres. The headquarters of the <a href="Archives%20of%20Republika%20Srpska">Archives of Republika Srpska</a> is situated in the building known as "Carska kuća" or Imperial House, built around 1880. It has been in continuous public use longer than any other structure in Banja Luka.
One of the best-known cultural sites in Banja Luka is the cultural centre of "<a href="Banski%20Dvor">Banski Dvor</a>" (Halls of the <a href="Ban%20%28title%29">Ban</a>), built in the 1930s as the residence for the Bans of the <a href="Vrbas%20Banovina">Vrbas Banovina</a>.
There is a number of Cultural Artistic Associations in the city. The oldest is CAA "Pelagić" (founded 1927), one of the oldest institutions of this kind in <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>.
Sport.
Banja Luka has one major <a href="association%20football">football</a> stadium and several indoor sports halls. The local <a href="handball">handball</a>, basketball and football teams bear the traditional name <a href="Borac%20Banja%20Luka">Borac</a> ("fighter"). There are sixteen football clubs in the city, with the most notable being Luka are <a href="FK%20Borac%20Banja%20Luka">Borac Banja Luka</a> (2020–2021 season champions of <a href="Premier%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Premier League of Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>), <a href="FK%20BSK%20Banja%20Luka">BSK Banja Luka</a>, and <a href="FK%20Omladinac%20Banja%20Luka">Omladinac Banja Luka</a> (both in the <a href="First%20League%20of%20the%20Republika%20Srpska">First League of the Republika Srpska</a>), FK Naprijed Banja Luka and FK Vrbas Banja Luka
<a href="FK%20Borac%20Banja%20Luka">FK Borac Banja Luka</a> is one of the most popular football club in the Republika Srpska. The club has won several major trophies in its history such as trophies as a champion of <a href="Mitropa%20Cup">Mitropa Cup</a>, <a href="Yugoslav%20Cup">Yugoslav Cup</a>, <a href="Premier%20League%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Premier League of Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina%20Football%20Cup">Bosnia and Herzegovina Football Cup</a>, <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20First%20League%20of%20the%20Republika%20Srpska">First League of the Republika Srpska</a>, <a href="Republika%20Srpska%20Cup">Republic Srpska Cup</a>. The club has participated in <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> and <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">UEFA Europa League</a>.
The city has a long tradition of handball. <a href="RK%20Borac%20Banja%20Luka">RK Borac Banja Luka</a> was the European Champion in <a href="1975%E2%80%9376%20European%20Cup%20%28handball%29">1976</a>, the European Vice-Champion in <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20European%20Cup%20%28handball%29">1975</a> and the winner of the IHF Cup in 1991.
The local tennis tournament, <a href="Banja%20Luka%20Challenger">"Memorijal Trive Vujića"</a>, has become professional and has been awarded <a href="Association%20of%20Tennis%20Professionals">ATP</a> status in 2001, with the rank of a <a href="ATP%20Challenger%20Series">Challenger</a>. The Banja Luka Challenger takes place in September each year. In 2006, the <a href="Davis%20Cup">Davis Cup</a> matches of the Europe/Africa Zone Group III took place in the city.
Since 2015, the city hosts the Banjaluka <a href="Half%20marathon">Half-marathon</a>.
In 2005 and 2019 the European Championships in <a href="Rafting">Rafting</a> were held on the Vrbas river.
Banja Luka was designated European city of sport in 2018.
Transport.
Public transportation within Banja Luka is exclusively operated by the bus services. Over thirty bus lines connect downtown with the rest of the city and its suburbs. The oldest bus link in the city is line No 1. Taxis are also readily available. The expressway E-661 (locally known as M-16) leads north to Croatia from Banja Luka by way of <a href="Gradi%C5%A1ka%2C%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Gradiška</a>, near the Bosnian/Croatian border. A wide range of bus services are available to most neighbouring and larger towns in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as to regional and European destinations such as Austria, Belgium, Croatia, Germany, France, Italy, Montenegro, The Netherlands, Serbia, Sweden, Switzerland and Slovakia.
Banja Luka is a minor hub of the railway services of <a href="Republika%20Srpska%20Railways">Željeznice Republike Srpske</a>, which comprises one half of the railway network of <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>. Services operate to most northern Bosnian towns, and two modern air-conditioned 'Talgo' trains run to <a href="Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a> every day. However, services are relatively slow and infrequent compared with neighbouring countries.
<a href="Banja%20Luka%20International%20Airport">Banja Luka International Airport</a> (<a href="IATA">IATA</a>: BNX, <a href="ICAO">ICAO</a>: LQBK) is located north of Banja Luka. The airport is served by <a href="Air%20Serbia">Air Serbia</a>, which operates flights to <a href="Belgrade%20Nikola%20Tesla%20Airport">Belgrade</a> and summer charters to <a href="Antalya%20Airport">Antalya</a> and <a href="Athens%20International%20Airport">Athens</a>, while <a href="Ryanair">Ryanair</a> operates flights to <a href="Orio%20al%20Serio%20International%20Airport">Bergamo</a>, <a href="Berlin%20Brandenburg%20Airport">Berlin</a>, <a href="Brussels%20South%20Charleroi%20Airport">Brussels</a>, <a href="G%C3%B6teborg%20Landvetter%20Airport">Gothenburg</a>, <a href="Memmingen%20Airport">Memmingen</a>, <a href="Frankfurt%E2%80%93Hahn%20Airport">Frankfurt–Hahn</a> and <a href="Vienna%20International%20Airport">Vienna</a>. There is also <a href="Banja%20Luka%20Zalu%C5%BEani%20Airfield">Banja Luka Zalužani Airfield</a>, a small airstrip.
